title: Can there be a planet just filled with water and no land as shown in the Interstellar movie? - Quora

response.answer_text: It would be much easier to have a wet layer around a rocky core. I’m having trouble understanding an entirely water planet unless it’s entirely ice. With water that deep, it seems it would be solidified at the core, but that much pressure would generate heat, prevent freezing….I guess I’ll have to set up a model to calculate. But I probably won’t come back to this question. And it’s still much easier to have a rocky core with a wet surface. Entirely wet, even. Miles deep.

Just because a planet is covered in water doesn’t mean there is no land….its just underneath the water (like the ocean floor on Earth, which contains its own landscape of ridges, trenches, mountains, etc….the highest points of which we call “land”). It’s not possible for a planet to have liquid water down to a core of liquid/solid metal.
